Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. ---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, bu

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everyting with a suspicious, c

Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Diff

Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.

The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United Sta

We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where educati

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many dec

This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate informa

Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizen

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try.

This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.

Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, be

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We aare

New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at th

New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, con

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real info

Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not f

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Everyone has a responsibility to do

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Everyone has a responsibility to do their very best t

This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Everyone has a responsibility to do their very best to find real info

If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Everyone has a responsibility to do their very best to find real information, and to

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Everyone has a responsibility to do their very best to find real information, and to take time to read

This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Everyone has a responsibility to do their very best to find real information, and to take time to read that informati

If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Everyone has a responsibility to do their very best to find real information, and to take time to read that information. It's not easy, but democracy

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Everyone has a responsibility to do their very best to find real information, and to take time to read that information. It's not easy, but democracy requires it and the people

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
 Differing opinions are the cornerstone of democracy, but today we have people purposefully filling news feeds with complete fabrications. In this day and age, news organizations are trying to fill the voids left behind by decline of investigative journalism. This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

This is particularly dangerous to the citizens of the United States, where education has been a very low priority for many decades. This has left many people in the US without the ability to critically think about the world they live in.

As difficult as it is to obtain accurate information, we as citizens have a duty to try. We need to understand the reality of our society, before we can begin to look for ways to change it in positive ways. If we actively seek out the truth, but hold on to our skepticism, it doesn't matter if we don't catch every piece of news. We are, at the very least, consuming real information and not fabrication.

Everyone has a responsibility to do their very best to find real information, and to take time to read that information. It's not easy, but democracy requires it and the people of the US need to take that seri

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

In my opinion, people should have at least a basic awareness of what's going on in the world. We can't make informed decisions at the voting poles, if we don't gather some information before we make our choices. Information, provided people actually take the time to learn from it, is terribly empowering. When we know what we are voting for, we can make responsible, informed decisions. If we don't, we aren't truly participating in the democratic process.

It's nearly impossible to keep up with every detail that comes across in a 24 hour news cycle. New organizations have a habit of sensationalizing everything, to the point that it's difficult to filtrate out all of the unimportant information that they produce. The recent election in the US taught us that it's difficult to determine what information is really true and what's just one person's opinion. Misinformation has hit new heights in the United States, adding a new, unwelcome dimension to the process of following the news. This is complicated even more when you add in all of the texts, tweets, e-mails, and facebook feeds that fill up a person's news Now, not only does a person need to process the massive amount of news available, to get their information, but they also need to read everything with a suspicious, critical mind. 
Even if people try to stay up-to-date, the sheer amount of news out there seems to be overwhelming.
